Colonoscopy shows superficial ulcerations in the terminal ileum (figure 1), erythema and granularity of the cecum and ascending colon, and a normal-appearing transverse colon (figure 2), descending colon, and rectum. Biopsies reveal mild active ileitis, mild chronic active colitis of the cecum and ascending colon, and normal colonic mucosa of the transverse and descending colon and rectum.
What is the best next step in evaluating for complications of the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT angiography would be considered if ischemia were the suspected cause of the patient’s abdominal pain. Ischemia can cause ulcerations in the small or large intestine, but this patient’s young age, ileocecal location of disease, and pathologic features are more suggestive of Crohn disease than ischemia.

B) CORRECT:

Crohn disease is the probable diagnosis in this patient given her right-lower-quadrant pain, chronic diarrhea, elevated C-reactive protein level, colonoscopy showing inflammation of the terminal ileum and ascending colon, and pathologic features of acute and chronic inflammation. The best next step is magnetic resonance enterography (MRE), especially because the patient’s weight loss seems out of proportion to the limited area of disease noted on colonoscopy, thereby raising the possibility of additional disease that has not yet been identified. MRE allows for further evaluation of the extent of small-bowel disease and assesses for complications, such as stricture or fistula, that might affect therapeutic decisions. Of note, this test uses coordinated oral and intravenous contrast; it does not expose the patient to radiation.

Key learning point: In suspected small-bowel Crohn disease that involves the terminal ileum and ascending colon on colonoscopy, evaluation of the extent of disease and assessment for complications is best performed with magnetic resonance enterography.

C) INCORRECT:

Video-capsule endoscopy can be used to evaluate for Crohn disease of the small intestine but is less specific than magnetic resonance enterography in identifying the location and extent of disease within the small bowel. In addition, there is a risk of the capsule getting stuck at the site of a narrow stricture, so patients suspected of having Crohn disease should undergo cross-sectional imaging to evaluate for stricture before undergoing video-capsule endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can mimic Crohn disease, but this typically occurs only in immunocompromised patients. In addition, testing for CMV involvement of the gastrointestinal tract is performed on endoscopic biopsies, not on stool samples. Testing for CMV infection should be considered in patients with inflammatory bowel disease who experience a flare while receiving immunosuppressive therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Fecal occult-blood testing would be indicated in a patient with microcytic anemia and possible occult blood loss. In this case, the patient’s microcytic anemia is most likely due to Crohn disease; she has already had a colonoscopy, so fecal occult-blood testing is not necessary.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man reports 3 months of diffuse, intermittent, crampy abdominal pain. He reports loose bowel movements twice daily, with an occasional formed stool. He has seen blood in the toilet on two occasions. His appetite is diminished, and his gastrointestinal symptoms are unrelated to his diet. A review of systems is otherwise negative. He was last seen in your practice one year ago and has lost 3 kg in weight since then.
On examination, the patient is in no distress. His conjunctivae are pale with no scleral icterus. There are no oral lesions. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant, without rebound or guarding. His perianal examination is normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8200
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.1
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
437,000
150,000–350,000


Albumin (g/L)
3.4
3.5–5.5


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome causes cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, nonbloody diarrhea, and constipation but is not associated with anemia or weight loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic colitis often manifests with several episodes of nonbloody diarrhea each day. It can be subdivided into lymphocytic colitis and collagenous colitis and has been associated with autoimmune diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum typically manifests with painless rectal bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is characterized by chronic inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract. It is categorized as either Crohn disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC). The two conditions share many common clinical and laboratory findings, and definitive diagnosis generally requires radiologic and endoscopic investigation as well as close monitoring of the progression of the disease.

CD manifests as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss; other common findings include poor appetite, fever, and iron deficiency. Abdominal examination may be normal but often reveals tenderness or fullness in the right lower quadrant; perianal examination may show skin tags, fistulae, or fissures.

UC symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain.

Laboratory findings associated with IBD include thrombocytosis, anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, some patients have normal laboratory results at the time of diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of several months of abdominal pain, loose stools, weight loss, hematochezia, and mild anemia in a young adult is inflammatory bowel disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Weight loss, diarrhea, and anemia can all be seen in celiac disease, but rectal bleeding is not a typical feature.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man is evaluated for 4 months of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He reports having two to three loose bowel movements on most days, with an occasional formed stool. He notes urgency with many bowel movements, and these are often bloody. He has not lost weight.
On examination, he has no pallor, scleral icterus, or oral lesions. His abdominal and perirectal examinations are normal. Stool studies are negative for infectious causes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The gastrointestinal symptoms of patients diagnosed with celiac disease include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, bloating, weight loss, and constipation. Rectal bleeding is distinctly unusual among patients with celiac disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic colitis (MC) can be subdivided into lymphocytic colitis and collagenous colitis and has been associated with autoimmune diseases. MC often manifests with several episodes of nonbloody diarrhea each day.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional gastrointestinal disorder that is associated with abdominal pain and an alteration in bowel habits. It is not associated with rectal bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal pain, diarrhea, and rectal bleeding are classic symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which consists of both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Other symptoms include malaise, fevers, weight loss, and abdominal cramping associated with fecal urgency.

Differentiating between Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis may require abdominal imaging and intestinal biopsies; small bowel involvement or a biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas would be consistent with a diagnosis of Crohn disease.

Key learning point: In a young adult who reports several months of bloody diarrhea and fecal urgency and whose stool cultures are negative, the most likely diagnosis is inflammatory bowel disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum is characterized by painless rectal bleeding, not diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting crampy, constant, diffuse abdominal pain for the past 2 months. He says that the pain is relieved immediately after bowel movements but returns soon thereafter. He has also experienced diarrhea during the past few weeks, typically about 5 times daily, and in the past week, he has noticed dark red blood and mucus in his stools. He also notes low-grade fevers, diminished appetite and energy, and a weight loss of 2.3 kg during the past month. He has no family history of gastrointestinal disorders, and the household has no pets. Three months ago, he traveled to Mexico with his family, but none of his relatives have had similar symptoms.
On physical examination, he has a temperature of 37.5°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/65 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He is alert, thin, and pale. He has no oral ulcerations, no joint swelling or tenderness, and no rashes. His abdomen is soft, and he has no masses or organomegaly. He has mild tenderness in the periumbilical region.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
12,000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.3
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)

41.0–53.0

Which one of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Colonoscopy with biopsies of the terminal ileum and colon
Nucleic acid amplification testing for Clostridioides difficile

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s history of bloody diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, weight loss, and low-grade fevers raises suspicion for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). His physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness but no peritoneal signs, and his laboratory results suggest a chronic inflammatory process and malabsorption as indicated by the elevated inflammatory markers, anemia, and hypoalbuminemia.

Inflammatory bowel disease can be further distinguished as either Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis. Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation throughout the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and may involve the ileum, the colon, or both. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by continuous inflammation of the mucosal layer with ulceration; the disease affects the rectum first and may extend into the more proximal colon.

Patients with IBD typically present with one or more of the following clinical features: loose stools, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Extraintestinal manifestations, such as oral ulcerations, uveitis, arthritis, and rash (erythema nodosum), may also occur and are more common in Crohn disease than ulcerative colitis.

Diagnosis of IBD involves laboratory testing, imaging, and colonoscopy. Anemia, elevated inflammatory markers, and hypoalbuminemia are typically seen (as in this case), but normal laboratory results do not exclude the diagnosis. Noninvasive imaging techniques that specifically evaluate the small bowel — such as magnetic resonance enterography (MRE), upper gastrointestinal (GI) series, and ultrasound — may be used during diagnostic evaluation and can assess the extent of the inflammation in patients with established IBD. Abdominal CT is not helpful in the evaluation of chronic diarrhea. However, colonoscopy with mucosal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing IBD and for differentiating between Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. The terminal ileum should be examined, and biopsies should be obtained throughout the small and large intestine. In addition, upper endoscopy is frequently performed to identify upper GI involvement of IBD and may be helpful to differentiate between ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease that involves only the colon.

Key learning point: The gold-standard test for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease is colonoscopy with biopsies of the terminal ileum and colon.

B) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum, a congenital anomaly of the GI tract that results from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct, can manifest with bloody stools and abdominal pain. A Meckel scan would be appropriate if suspicion for this condition were high, but IBD is the more likely diagnosis in this patient, given his hypoalbuminemia and elevated platelet count, indicating an ongoing inflammatory process, and his clinical presentation (including weight loss). Although complications of Meckel diverticulum can occur at any age, patients with this condition typically present before 10 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT is not helpful in the evaluation of chronic diarrhea. However, noninvasive imaging techniques that specifically evaluate the small bowel — such as magnetic resonance enterography (MRE), upper gastrointestinal (GI) series, and ultrasound — may be used during diagnostic evaluation and can assess the extent of the inflammation in patients with established IBD.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious causes should be considered in any patient with chronic diarrhea, particularly one who has traveled recently, but the protracted course of symptoms in this particular case makes an infectious cause unlikely. Although stool studies are reasonable to obtain in this patient, testing for Clostridioides difficile alone is not a suitable screening approach for chronic diarrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder that leads to inflammation of the small intestine, manifests with many of the same symptoms as IBD, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, low-grade fevers, bloody stools, and elevated inflammatory markers are typically not present. Although testing this patient for celiac disease would not be inappropriate, IBD is much higher on the list of differential diagnoses, and an endoscopic evaluation is necessary.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman reports having intermittent abdominal pain for the past year that has worsened during the past 2 weeks. She describes it as a sharp, shooting pain that occurs mainly in the epigastric region and that improves after bowel movements. During the past 2 weeks, she has also developed loose stools, most of which are dark red in color. She reports having about 5 stools per day. Six months ago, she saw another provider for similar symptoms and had normal findings on an abdominal radiograph, basic laboratory testing, and celiac antibody testing.
Today she notes that she fatigues easily and has pain in her right knee and hip, for which she takes naproxen daily. She has no known weight loss but says that the abdominal pain has diminished her appetite.
On physical examination, she appears thin and pale. She has a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 89 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. She has two superficial linear ulcerations along her buccal mucosa that are tender to the touch. Her abdomen is soft and diffusely tender, although she has no masses, rebound tenderness, or guarding. Perianal examination reveals a 7-mm skin tag on the left lateral side of the anus and a 6-mm skin tag on the right lateral side. Joint examination reveals tenderness and mild swelling over the right knee joint. She has no rashes.
What additional clinical or radiologic evidence would aid in the correct diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Evidence of osteoporosis on a bone mineral density scan
Evidence of small-bowel wall thickening and narrowing of the terminal ileum on an upper gastrointestinal series with small-bowel follow-through
Evidence of scleral icterus and jaundice on physical examination
Evidence of gastritis or duodenitis on endoscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Evidence of osteoporosis may be seen in patients with IBD due to weight loss, malabsorption, chronic inflammation, and treatment with glucocorticoids, but it would not help in further classifying the disorder as Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and physical findings raise suspicion for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly Crohn disease.

Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation. It can involve any component of the gastrointestinal tract but most often affects the small bowel. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation of the mucosal layer; it usually affects the rectum with proximal spread to the colon.

Patients with IBD typically present with one or more of the following clinical features: loose stools, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Extraintestinal manifestations occur in about 10% of patients with IBD and are more common in Crohn disease than in ulcerative colitis. Such manifestations include oral ulcerations, erythema nodosum, scleritis, arthritis, and perianal fistulae, abscesses, or large skin tags (usually >5 mm). Notably, the arthritis in patients with Crohn disease typically affects large joints, such as the knees, hips, and wrists. This patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms in combination with the presence of oral ulcerations, perianal skin tags, and large-joint arthritis suggests a diagnosis of Crohn disease.

Magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) and an upper gastrointestinal (GI) series with small-bowel follow-through both allow for visualization of the small bowel and can help to distinguish Crohn disease from ulcerative colitis. Characteristic findings of Crohn disease include narrowing or obstruction of the terminal ileum, patchy inflammation of the small bowel and colon, and enteric fistulae. In contrast, imaging studies of ulcerative colitis show diffuse involvement of the rectum and distal colon without any involvement of the small bowel. This patient’s symptoms and physical findings are most consistent with Crohn disease. Definitive diagnosis would require colonoscopy.

Key learning point: Evidence of small-bowel wall thickening and narrowing of the terminal ileum on an upper gastrointestinal series with small-bowel follow-through is most suggestive of Crohn disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Although most IBD-associated extraintestinal conditions are more common in Crohn disease than ulcerative colitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an exception. Patients with PSC typically present with intermittent jaundice, pruritus, and malaise — and have elevated levels of aminotransferases and gamma-glutamyltransferase. PSC is far more common in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn disease; thus, a finding of jaundice or scleral icterus with abnormal liver enzymes would argue more in favor of ulcerative colitis than Crohn disease. This patient’s clinical findings are more consistent with Crohn disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although small-bowel involvement is a feature of Crohn disease and not ulcerative colitis, a finding of nonspecific gastritis on upper endoscopy would not help to distinguish between the two disorders. In one published study, patients with ulcerative colitis and those with Crohn disease both had findings of gastritis or duodenitis.

E) INCORRECT:

A history of perioral hyperpigmentation is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, an intestinal polyp syndrome that can cause intestinal bleeding and, if the polyps lead to obstruction, abdominal pain. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not a cause of loose stools and would not be consistent with this patient’s presentation.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy reports 3 months of diffuse, intermittent, crampy abdominal pain. He was last seen in your practice one year ago. He reports loose bowel movements twice daily, with an occasional formed stool. He has seen blood in the toilet on two occasions. His appetite is diminished, and his gastrointestinal symptoms are unrelated to his diet. A review of systems is otherwise negative. His growth chart is provided (figure).
On examination, the patient is in no distress. His conjunctivae are pale with no scleral icterus. There are no oral lesions. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant, without rebound or guarding. His perianal examination is normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8200
4500–13,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.1
11.5–15.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
437,000
150,000–450,000


Albumin (g/L)
3.4
3.5–5.5


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is characterized by chronic inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract. It is categorized as either Crohn disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC). The two conditions share many common clinical and laboratory findings, and definitive diagnosis generally requires radiologic and endoscopic investigation as well as close monitoring of the progression of the disease.

CD manifests as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss; other common findings include poor appetite, fever, and iron deficiency. In some cases, growth failure is the only sign of CD. Abdominal examination in children with CD may be normal but often reveals tenderness or fullness in the right lower quadrant; perianal examination may show skin tags, fistulae, or fissures.

UC symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain.

Laboratory findings associated with IBD include thrombocytosis, anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, some children have normal laboratory results at the time of diagnosis. In children with IBD, the mean age at diagnosis is 12.5 years.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of several months of abdominal pain, loose stools, and hematochezia in an adolescent boy who is underweight and mildly anemic is inflammatory bowel disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Failure to thrive, decreased height velocity, and growth failure can all be seen in celiac disease, but rectal bleeding is not a typical feature.

C) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum typically manifests with painless rectal bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome causes abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and nonbloody stools but is not associated with anemia or weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic colitis often manifests with several episodes of nonbloody diarrhea each day. It can be subdivided into lymphocytic colitis and collagenous colitis and has been associated with autoimmune diseases. It most commonly occurs in adults.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is evaluated for 4 months of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He reports having two to three loose bowel movements on most days, with an occasional formed stool. He notes urgency with many bowel movements, and often these are bloody. He has not lost weight and continues to be at the 40th percentile for growth.
On examination, he has no pallor, scleral icterus, or oral lesions. His abdominal and perirectal examinations are normal. Stool studies are negative for infectious causes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum is characterized by painless rectal bleeding, not diarrhea.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal pain, diarrhea, and rectal bleeding are classic symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which consists of both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. About one-third of children with IBD present with moderate symptoms, including malaise, fevers, weight loss, and abdominal cramping associated with fecal urgency. In some children, growth failure may be the presenting sign of IBD.

Differentiating between Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis may require abdominal imaging and intestinal biopsies; small bowel involvement or a biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas would be consistent with a diagnosis of Crohn disease.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent with several months of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fecal urgency who recently noted blood in the toilet and whose stool cultures are negative is inflammatory bowel disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional gastrointestinal disorder that is associated with abdominal pain and an alteration in bowel habits. It is not associated with rectal bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Microscopic colitis (MC), which is more typical in adults than children, can be subdivided into lymphocytic colitis and collagenous colitis and has been associated with autoimmune diseases. MC often manifests with several episodes of nonbloody diarrhea each day.

E) INCORRECT:

The gastrointestinal symptoms of older children diagnosed with celiac disease include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, bloating, weight loss, and constipation. Rectal bleeding is distinctly unusual among children with celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with a 6-month history of unilateral knee pain and swelling. Each morning he has stiffness that persists for at least an hour, and his daytime activity is limited by pain. He has also noted a painful, bumpy rash on his shins, recurrent mouth ulcers, intermittent abdominal pain, frequent bowel movements, and fatigue. He has lost approximately 4.5 kg during the past 3 months.
His vital signs are unremarkable other than a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. He is thin, with a BMI of 17.5 (8th percentile). He has three oral ulcers. His abdomen is diffusely tender with no masses or hepatosplenomegaly.
He has tenderness and decreased range of motion in his right knee, with a measurable effusion. The hips, left knee, and ankles are all normal. He has 5 to 10 tender, red nodules on both of his shins.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.9
13.0–16.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
69
78–98


Albumin (g/dL)
2.6
3.5–5.5


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm per hour)
55
0–13


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
35
0–5


Uric acid (mg/dL)
3.1
3.0–7.7


Serologic testing for Lyme disease, rheumatoid factor, and anti-citrullinated peptic antibodies is negative.
Aspiration of the right knee joint yields 55 mL of nonbloody but cloudy yellow fluid with a nucleated cell count of 13,200 per mm3 (25% polymorphonucleated cells). Analysis by compensated polarized light microscopy is negative for the presence of any crystals. Gram stain and culture are negative for any microorganisms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Joint pain is a common extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), affecting approximately 25% of children with IBD. Joint inflammation in IBD can involve the sacroiliac joint and axial skeleton (similar to ankylosing spondylitis), or it can be a peripheral arthritis, dactylitis, or tenosynovitis. IBD arthropathy should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion, even in a patient with known IBD; alternative diagnoses could include septic arthritis, Lyme arthritis, microcrystalline arthritis, or other forms of autoimmune arthritis.

Other common extraintestinal manifestations of IBD are oral ulcers, anemia, and erythema nodosum. Gastrointestinal symptoms usually precede joint disease by months to years, but they can also occur simultaneously, or the joint symptoms can precede the gastrointestinal symptoms.

A diagnosis of IBD should be suspected in any patient who has arthritis accompanied by lower abdominal pain, hematochezia, unexplained weight loss, anemia, or fever.

The arthritis that accompanies IBD typically improves after effective treatment of the bowel disease. However, the axial involvement in IBD is much more likely to persist and progress independent of the activity of the bowel disease.

In this case, septic arthritis has been ruled out by microbiologic analysis of joint fluid. Gonococcal arthritis remains an unlikely possibility and could be ruled out by testing for gonococcus. Sarcoid arthritis could manifest as a chronic inflammatory arthritis, erythema nodosum, and wasting. If this patient did not demonstrate other features of IBD, then one would need to consider biopsy of an affected organ or tissue to assess for the presence of noncaseating granulomas of sarcoid.

Key learning point: The most likely underlying diagnosis in an adolescent with inflammatory arthritis, diarrhea, oral ulcers, anemia, and erythema nodosum is inflammatory bowel disease.

B) INCORRECT:

The arthritis with SLE is usually a small-joint inflammatory polyarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

The low-normal serum uric acid level and the lack of crystals on joint fluid analysis make gouty arthritis very unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Serologic analysis rules out Lyme arthritis (which invariably is positive in the setting of the chronic monoarthritis phase).

E) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and gouty arthritis can all initially manifest with joint pain. However, the constellation of symptoms described in this patient is not fully consistent with any of these clinical entities.

Although stool studies are reasonable to obtain in this patient, testing for Clostridioides difficile alone is not a suitable screening approach for chronic diarrhea.

The terminal ileum should be examined, and biopsies should be obtained throughout the small and large intestine. In addition, upper endoscopy is frequently performed to identify upper GI involvement of IBD and may be helpful to differentiate between ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease that involves only the colon.

Key learning point: The gold-standard test for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease is colonoscopy with biopsies of the terminal ileum and colon.

C) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder that leads to inflammation of the small intestine, manifests with many of the same symptoms as IBD, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, growth failure, and delayed puberty. However, low-grade fevers, bloody stools, and elevated inflammatory markers are typically not present. Although testing this patient for celiac disease would not be inappropriate, IBD is much higher on the list of differential diagnoses, and an endoscopic evaluation is necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum, a congenital anomaly of the GI tract that results from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct, can manifest with bloody stools and abdominal pain. A Meckel scan would be appropriate if suspicion for this condition were high, but IBD is the more likely diagnosis in this patient, given his hypoalbuminemia and elevated platelet count, indicating an ongoing inflammatory process, and his clinical presentation (including weight loss). Although complications of Meckel diverticulum can occur at any age, patients with this condition typically present before 10 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT is not helpful in the evaluation of chronic diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl reports having intermittent abdominal pain for the past year that has worsened during the past 2 weeks. She describes it as a sharp, shooting pain that occurs mainly in the epigastric region and that improves after bowel movements. During the past 2 weeks, she has also developed loose stools, most of which are dark red in color. She reports having about 5 stools per day. Six months ago, she saw another provider for similar symptoms and had normal findings on an abdominal radiograph, basic laboratory testing, and celiac antibody testing.
Today she notes that she fatigues easily and has pain in her right knee and hip, for which she takes naproxen daily. She has no known weight loss but says that the abdominal pain has diminished her appetite.
On physical examination, she appears thin and pale. She has a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 89 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. She has two superficial linear ulcerations along her buccal mucosa that are tender to the touch. Her abdomen is soft and diffusely tender, although she has no masses, rebound tenderness, or guarding. Rectal examination reveals a 7-mm skin tag on the left lateral side and a 6-mm skin tag on the right lateral side. Joint examination reveals tenderness and mild swelling over the right knee joint. She has no rashes.
What additional clinical or radiologic evidence would aid in the correct diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Evidence of scleral icterus and jaundice on physical examination
Evidence of gastritis or duodenitis on endoscopy
Evidence of diminished growth velocity on the growth chart and delayed onset of menarche
Evidence of small-bowel wall thickening and narrowing of the terminal ileum on magnetic resonance enterography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although most IBD-associated extraintestinal conditions are more common in Crohn disease than ulcerative colitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an exception. Patients with PSC typically present with intermittent jaundice, pruritus, and malaise — and have elevated levels of aminotransferases and gamma-glutamyltransferase. PSC is far more common in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn disease; thus, a finding of jaundice or scleral icterus with abnormal liver enzymes would argue more in favor of ulcerative colitis than Crohn disease. This patient’s clinical findings are more consistent with Crohn disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Although small-bowel involvement is a feature of Crohn disease and not ulcerative colitis, a finding of nonspecific gastritis on upper endoscopy would not help to distinguish between the two disorders. In one published study, patients with ulcerative colitis and those with Crohn disease both had findings of gastritis or duodenitis.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of perioral hyperpigmentation is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, an intestinal polyp syndrome that can cause intestinal bleeding and, if the polyps lead to obstruction, abdominal pain. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not a cause of loose stools and would not be consistent with this patient’s presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Evidence of diminished growth velocity and delayed menarche may contribute to the diagnosis of IBD but would not help in further classifying the disorder as Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and physical findings raise suspicion for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly Crohn disease.

Crohn disease is the major form of IBD in childhood and adolescence and is characterized by transmural inflammation. It can involve any component of the gastrointestinal tract but most often affects the small bowel. Ulcerative colitis is less common in childhood and is characterized by inflammation of the mucosal layer; it usually affects the rectum with proximal spread to the colon.

Children with IBD typically present with one or more of the following clinical features: loose stools, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, tenesmus, growth failure, and delayed puberty. Extraintestinal manifestations occur in about 10% of patients with IBD and are more common in Crohn disease than in ulcerative colitis. Such manifestations include oral ulcerations, erythema nodosum, scleritis, arthritis, and perianal fistulae, abscesses, or large skin tags (usually >5 mm). Notably, the arthritis in patients with Crohn disease typically affects large joints, such as the knees, hips, and wrists. This patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms in combination with the presence of oral ulcerations, perianal skin tags, and large-joint arthritis suggests a diagnosis of Crohn disease.

Magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) allows for visualization of the small bowel and can help to distinguish Crohn disease from ulcerative colitis. Other imaging modalities (such as CT enterography or small-bowel follow-through) can also demonstrate these findings but carry a radiation burden to the patient. Characteristic findings of Crohn disease include narrowing or obstruction of the terminal ileum, patchy inflammation of the small bowel and colon, and enteric fistulae. In contrast, imaging studies of ulcerative colitis show diffuse involvement of the rectum and distal colon without any involvement of the small bowel. This patient’s symptoms and physical findings are most consistent with Crohn disease. Definitive diagnosis would require colonoscopy.

Key learning point: Evidence of small-bowel wall thickening and narrowing of the terminal ileum on magnetic resonance enterography is most suggestive of Crohn disease.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young woman who was diagnosed with Crohn disease 6 months ago presents with pain in her right hip and right ankle as well as morning stiffness lasting about an hour. She first noticed the pain 2 weeks ago when she was climbing a flight of stairs.
Further questioning reveals that the hip pain is worst in the mid-buttock area. The patient’s right ankle, which has been intermittently swollen, is most painful in the mornings. She has also noticed stiffness in her left hand in the morning. She completed a course of oral prednisone 4 weeks ago for a flare of her Crohn disease and is currently maintained on mesalamine. She is afebrile and has no complaints other than her joint discomfort.
Her examination is notable for swelling and tenderness over the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints on her left hand and swelling and mild erythema of the right ankle with probable effusion. She has minimal pain with flexion of the hip but has right hip pain with simultaneous flexion, abduction, and external rotation (FABER test) of the left hip. She also has right hip pain with thigh thrust of the right hip. She has no rashes, oral ulcers, or alopecia.
Laboratory tests are negative for antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs). The patient has a C-reactive protein level of 14 mg/liter (reference range, 0.08–3.10), and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 40 mm/hr (1–25). Liver function tests and a complete blood count with differential are normal.
Which one of the following treatments would be most appropriate to add to this patient’s regimen at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is generally not effective in inducing remission when joint effusions are present, so this patient may eventually need a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) such as sulfasalazine or methotrexate; however, use of these drugs would be premature at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Biologic agents such as tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (including adalimumab and infliximab) and the interleukin-12/23 inhibitor ustekinumab are reserved for when NSAIDs and DMARDs are not effective in controlling pain and inflammation; these agents are not first-line therapy for IBD-associated arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Biologic agents such as tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (including adalimumab and infliximab) and the interleukin-12/23 inhibitor ustekinumab are reserved for when NSAIDs and DMARDs are not effective in controlling pain and inflammation; these agents are not first-line therapy for IBD-associated arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Pauciarticular arthritis and pain in the hip girdle, back, or buttock of a patient who had a recent flare of Crohn disease is consistent with a diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)-associated arthritis. The presence of findings consistent with sacroiliitis rather than inflammation of the hip or lumbar spine is typical of IBD-associated arthritis. This condition, which can be acute or chronic, can affect the sacroiliac joints (unilaterally or bilaterally), spine, and peripheral joints (usually fewer than six). Flares of peripheral joint arthritis often coincide with flares of IBD but not always. Axial spondyloarthritis activity (e.g., sacroiliitis) does not necessarily parallel IBD activity.

First-line therapy for IBD-associated arthritis consists of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which are often used successfully even though they may worsen bowel inflammation. Cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors such as celecoxib cause less gastritis than nonselective NSAIDs and do not need to be given with a proton pump inhibitor.

Key learning point: The best initial treatment for arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication like celecoxib.

E) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is generally not effective in inducing remission when joint effusions are present, so this patient may eventually need a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) such as sulfasalazine or methotrexate; however, use of these drugs would be premature at this time.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-year history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. She has also had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 10 months. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the anterior aspect of both legs. There is a small draining lesion in the perianal region. Further evaluation of this patient's gastrointestinal tract is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Villous atrophy is a typical histopathologic finding in celiac disease. This condition can manifest with abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, extraintestinal symptoms are more common (e.g., vitamin deficiencies, dermatitis herpetiformis, depression, osteoporosis). This patient's erythema nodosum and fistulas are not associated with celiac disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of duodenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Intraepithelial lymphocytosis (examples indicated by arrowheads), villous atrophy (dashed outline showing the approximate height of a normal villus), and crypt hyperplasia (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Crypt abscesses are a typical histopathologic finding in ulcerative colitis (UC). They are also seen in patients with CD but are far more common in patients with UC. UC can manifest with erythema nodosum, severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. However, it is quite rare to see fistula formation in UC because inflammation is localized in the mucosal and submucosal layers.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

No structural abnormalities of the gastrointestinal tract in a patient with abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea would be concerning for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Though IBS could cause some of this patient's symptoms, it is not associated with findings like erythema nodosum or fistulas. In addition, patients with IBS generally appear healthy and do not typically manifest with weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuroendocrine tumor cells are found in carcinoid tumors. Diarrhea and abdominal cramps may occur as part of carcinoid syndrome, but they are usually accompanied by other findings such as cutaneous flushing and bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea). Moreover, carcinoid tumors are not associated with erythema nodosum or fistulas.

E) CORRECT:

Transmural intestinal inflammation is a characteristic finding of CD. It commonly results in abscess and fistula formation. Endoscopy confirms the diagnosis, showing a discontinuous pattern of involvement with linear ulcers (“snail trails”) and a cobblestone appearance of the affected GI areas (typically terminal ileum and colon). Biopsy reveals inflammation of all intestinal layers and noncaseating granulomas.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a colon biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Infiltrating neutrophils (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the crypts in the upper part of the image. A noncaseating granuloma (green overlay) is visible in the lower part of the image.

These features indicate transmural inflammation, which is a characteristic finding of Crohn disease.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a perianal fistula with drainage in combination with erythema nodosum (multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the legs) are suggestive of a diagnosis of Crohn disease (CD).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right-sided back pain, nausea, and dark urine. He reports alternating episodes of decreased urine output followed by a temporary increase in urine output for the past 2 days. In the past year, he has had two urinary tract infections. He has Crohn disease and underwent a small bowel resection 5 years ago. He currently takes mesalamine and a multivitamin. Examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. Which of the following factors has most likely contributed most to this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A parathyroid gland adenoma could cause pathologically increased secretion of parathyroid hormone and lead to clinical hyperparathyroidism. This often results in hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, which contribute to calcium stone formation. These stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate stones, but the risk of calcium phosphate stones is also increased. This patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., weakness, constipation, irritability), making hyperparathyroidism less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective tubular amino acid reabsorption is the underlying cause of cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder that increases the risk of cystine stones. However, in cystinuria, stone formation would typically manifest in childhood and hexagon-shaped crystals would be seen on urinalysis, rather than the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, a positive sodium nitroprusside test would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) increase the risk of struvite stones. This patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections; however, they are unlikely to be the cause of his stones. Struvite stones would appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid appearance) on urinalysis, not the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Struvite stones are often quite large and fill the entire renal pelvis and calyces on imaging studies.

D) CORRECT:

Malabsorption of fatty acids due to deficiency in bile acids is common in patients with Crohn disease (and/or short bowel syndrome) and likely explains this patient's nephrolithiasis. In the intestinal lumen, undigested fatty acids chelate calcium, which would normally bind oxalate and lead to its excretion in the feces. Patients with Crohn disease often have pathologically increased luminal oxalate and increased oxalate absorption. After entering the serum, oxalate is excreted in the urine (hyperoxaluria), where it binds calcium and forms calcium oxalate stones.

Episodes of increased urination followed by oliguria are caused by temporary ureteral obstruction by stones. If a ureter is blocked, urine cannot pass through. When the obstruction is relieved, copious urine flows into the bladder.

E) INCORRECT:

High urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, which appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. An alkaline environment increases the concentration of dibasic phosphate (HPO42-) in the urine, which is prone to bind to dicationic calcium (Ca2+) to form calcium phosphate stones. A high urine pH is also a risk factor for the formation of struvite stones, which appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lids) on urinalysis. In contrast, a low urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of oxalate stones.
questions.hint: Envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis indicate calcium oxalate crystals.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-week history of fatigue, watery diarrhea, and cramping abdominal pain. He has also had pain in the mouth and gums for 6 days. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows two 1-cm, tender ulcers in the mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 77 μm3, leukocyte count is 11,800/mm3, and platelet count is 360,000/mm3. Colonoscopy with biopsy of the colonic mucosa is performed. Analysis of the specimen shows noncaseating granulomas and neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diverticulitis can manifest with fever, leukocytosis, abdominal pain, and changes in bowel habits. Smoking is also a known risk factor for diverticulitis. The pain associated with this condition is, however, usually localized to the left lower quadrant. In addition, diverticulitis more commonly causes constipation rather than diarrhea. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with suspected acute diverticulitis because of the high risk of perforation. Moreover, colon biopsy and histopathological studies are not routinely performed in patients with diverticulitis.

B) CORRECT:

Crohn disease has a bimodal distribution of age of onset and can develop in older patients approx. 60 years of age, and smoking is a strong risk factor. This condition typically manifests with chronic, watery, nonbloody diarrhea and abdominal pain (mainly in the right lower quadrant). Common laboratory findings include microcytic anemia and leukocytosis, both of which are seen here. Extraintestinal manifestations, such as the oral aphthae in this patient, are often also present. Biopsy results showing granulomatous inflammation of the colonic mucosa are diagnostic of Crohn disease.

Key learning point: Crohn disease often presents with chronic, watery diarrhea, right lower quadrant pain, oral ulcers, microcytic anemia, and noncaseating granulomas on biopsy, and is strongly associated with smoking.

C) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can also manifest with diarrhea and abdominal pain. This condition classically develops during infancy but can also result in symptoms in the third or fourth decades of life; it is an unlikely diagnosis in this 61-year-old patient. In addition, villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltration of the small intestine would be seen on histopathologic examination instead of granulomatous inflammation and neutrophilic cryptitis of the colon.

D) INCORRECT:

Behcet disease can manifest with painful oral ulcers, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. However, this patient does not have other typical findings of Behcet disease, including genital ulcers and lesions of the skin (e.g., erythema nodosum), eye (e.g., anterior uveitis, retinal vasculitis), and vasculature (e.g., phlebitis, deep vein thrombosis). Moreover, granulomatous inflammation is not a histopathologic finding of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) can develop in individuals approx. 60 years of age and manifests with chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. While neutrophilic cryptitis is a common finding in patients with UC, the granulomas seen on this patient's biopsy are not consistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, oral ulcers are not associated with UC, and the diarrhea associated with this condition is typically bloody and occurs with greater frequency (often > 10 times daily).
questions.hint: This patient has a common inflammatory disease that has a bimodal distribution of age of onset. It is most often diagnosed in patients 15–35 years of age, but 10% of cases are diagnosed at approx. 60 years of age.

questions.text: A previously healthy, 24-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-week history of loose, nonbloody stools. He also reports abdominal pain, intermittent nausea, and fever. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness of the right lower abdomen without rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies show a leukocytosis count and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. A CT scan of the abdomen shows transmural thickening and surrounding fat stranding of discrete regions of the terminal ileum and transverse colon. A colonoscopy is performed and biopsy specimens of the affected areas of the colon are taken. Which of the following findings is most specific for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Poorly differentiated gland-forming cells with desmoplasia
Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil-rich pseudomembranes are a histopathologic finding of clostridium enterocolitis, which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fevers. However, clostridium enterocolitis typically presents following antibiotic treatment, which facilitates overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile in the intestinal tract. Unlike in this patient, the loose stools are usually watery and characteristically foul-smelling. Inflammation of the colonic mucosa causes fibrinous exudate, which manifests as pseudomembranes.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the colon

The colonic mucosa is erythematous and edematous. Fibrin exudate has formed partially confluent, yellow plaques over the mucosa (referred to as “pseudomembranes”).

These findings are diagnostic of pseudomembranous colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Poorly differentiated gland-forming cells with desmoplasia of the surrounding connective tissue is a histopathologic finding of colon cancer, which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, and nausea. However, colon cancer would be unlikely in a 24-year-old patient without a significant family history. Moreover, it would have likely appeared as a soft tissue density narrowing the bowel lumen on abdominal CT scan.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of colonic tissue (H&E stain)

Colonic glands, which should only be present in the mucosal layer, are visible in all the layers of the colonic wall, including the outermost serosal layer (pT3). The glands are lined by tall columnar epithelial cells with basally oriented nuclei. The lumen of these glands contains necrotic debris. Goblet cells (which would appear as unstained cells between the lining of epithelial cells) are absent. The fibrous tissue surrounding the tumor cells indicates desmoplasia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

Formation of noncaseating granulomas is a histopathological finding in ∼ 30% of patients with CD. While the absence of granulomas does not rule out CD, their presence helps to distinguish CD from ulcerative colitis. This distinction can be challenging, especially in CD involving the colon. Distinguishing between the two conditions is crucial, however, as their management differs significantly. On biopsy, the presence of granulomatous inflammation, transmural inflammation, fissures, and aphthous ulcers would strongly suggest CD.

See “Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the cecum (H&E stain; low magnification)

Large numbers of lymphocytes, giant cells, and epithelioid cells are seen clustered around a large granuloma.

This is a typical histological finding in Crohn disease.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa is a histopathologic finding of ulcerative colitis (UC), which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fever. However, stool in UC is typically grossly bloody and contains mucus. Additionally, a CT scan of the abdomen would most likely show continuous inflammation starting in the rectum, in contrast to the discrete regions of inflammation in this patient.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudopolyps can be found in Crohn disease (CD), but they are not specific to the condition. In fact, they are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis (UC). UC may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fever. However, stool in UC is typically grossly bloody and contains mucus. A CT scan of the abdomen would most likely show continuous inflammation starting in the rectum, in contrast to the discrete regions of inflammation in this patient.
questions.hint: This young man has abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, laboratory evidence of inflammation, and a CT scan of the abdomen showing skip lesions in the colon with transmural inflammation and sparing of the rectum. Given that the infectious workup was negative, autoimmune enteritis is high on the differential. Crohn disease (CD) is more likely than ulcerative colitis based on the CT scan and the absence of tenesmus, gross bleeding, and rectal pain.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with three months of gradually worsening watery diarrhea, abdominal discomfort in the right lower quadrant, and multiple oral ulcers. He reports an unintentional weight loss of 6 kg during this period. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. There is no rectal bleeding. Laboratory findings show mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis typically presents with bloody diarrhea due to continuous colonic mucosal inflammation starting in the rectum. The absence of rectal bleeding and the presence of right lower quadrant discomfort suggest involvement of the terminal ileum, which is not typical for ulcerative colitis. Oral ulcers and systemic inflammation further support a diagnosis other than ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease primarily affects the proximal small intestine, leading to malabsorption and symptoms like steatorrhea and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Right lower quadrant tenderness suggests terminal ileum involvement, not typical for celiac disease. While oral ulcers can occur, they are not a hallmark. The systemic inflammatory response seen here is not characteristic of celiac disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder characterized by episodic abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits without systemic findings. The patient's weight loss, anemia, and elevated inflammatory markers indicate an inflammatory process, inconsistent with IBS. Oral ulcers and localized right lower quadrant tenderness further suggest an organic pathology rather than IBS.

D) CORRECT:

Crohn disease manifests with chronic watery diarrhea, right lower quadrant abdominal discomfort, and weight loss, often due to its involvement of the distal ileum and proximal colon. Oral ulcers are a notable extraintestinal manifestation, reflecting systemic inflammation. The disease's transmural inflammation can lead to complications like strictures and fistulas, although early stages primarily show inflammatory changes. Elevated inflammatory markers and anemia further indicate active inflammation. These clinical features align with Crohn disease's pathophysiology, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: Crohn disease can present with non-bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and oral ulcers, and is often associated with right lower quadrant tenderness due to ileal involvement.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with 4 months of progressively worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain that often increases after meals. He reports nonbloody diarrhea up to five times daily with occasional mucus and has lost 4 kg in this period. Over the past two weeks, he has also experienced low-grade fevers. On examination, bowel sounds are hyperactive, and the right lower quadrant is tender without rebound. Digital rectal examination reveals a small anal fissure but no masses (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
113 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
22 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


WBC
11 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L



Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis typically presents with continuous inflammation starting in the rectum, leading to left-sided abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. The right lower quadrant pain and nonbloody diarrhea in this patient are atypical. Anal fissures are more associated with transmural inflammation, unlike the mucosal involvement in ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease causes malabsorption, presenting with diarrhea and weight loss. However, the right lower quadrant pain, postprandial worsening, and systemic inflammation (elevated C-reactive protein, leukocytosis) are atypical. Anal fissures are uncommon in celiac disease, which primarily involves gluten-mediated small intestinal injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder characterized by abdominal pain and altered bowel habits without inflammatory markers or systemic symptoms. This patient’s fever, weight loss, and laboratory abnormalities suggest an inflammatory process. The anal fissure and localized pain further indicate an organic pathology, unlike IBS.

D) CORRECT:

Crohn disease manifests with chronic transmural inflammation, often affecting the terminal ileum, leading to right lower quadrant pain that worsens postprandially due to increased intestinal motility. Nonbloody diarrhea and weight loss reflect malabsorption and inflammation. Laboratory findings of anemia, elevated C-reactive protein, and leukocytosis indicate systemic inflammation. An anal fissure suggests perianal disease, a common complication due to deep ulcerations. Colonoscopy typically shows patchy inflammation, skip lesions, and a cobblestone appearance, consistent with Crohn disease pathophysiology.

Key learning point: Crohn disease is characterized by non-contiguous (skip) lesions and transmural inflammation, often affecting the terminal ileum and proximal colon, and can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with 6 months of persistent diarrhea, frequently associated with lower abdominal cramping and occasional blood in the stool. She has lost 4 kg and experienced low-grade fevers about once or twice per month during this period. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant and a small anal fissure. Laboratory studies show mild anemia.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious colitis usually presents as an acute, self-limited condition resolving within days to weeks. The 6-month duration of symptoms, along with intermittent fevers, weight loss, and anemia, suggests a chronic inflammatory process. Right lower quadrant tenderness and anal fissures are not typical of infectious colitis, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Crohn disease manifests with chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, often affecting the terminal ileum. This condition presents with persistent diarrhea, weight loss, and intermittent low-grade fevers, as seen in this young patient. Right lower quadrant tenderness suggests terminal ileum involvement. The presence of an anal fissure indicates perianal involvement, a hallmark of the transmural inflammation characteristic of Crohn disease. Transmural inflammation can lead to complications such as fissures and fistulas, distinguishing it from conditions with only mucosal involvement. Mild anemia reflects chronic inflammation affecting nutrient absorption and mucosal integrity.

Key learning point: Crohn disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and blood in the stool, often with systemic symptoms like fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder characterized by abdominal cramping and diarrhea without systemic features. The presence of low-grade fevers, weight loss, anemia, and blood in the stool suggests an organic inflammatory process. Right lower quadrant tenderness and anal fissures are inconsistent with IBS, which lacks mucosal inflammation or ulceration.

D) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis typically presents with continuous mucosal inflammation starting at the rectum, often causing left-sided abdominal pain. Right lower quadrant tenderness and anal fissures are atypical. The inflammation in ulcerative colitis is limited to the mucosa, rarely causing perianal complications. The patient's symptoms and findings do not align with the classic presentation of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with Crohn disease experiences recurrent flare-ups and smokes one pack daily. What is the most effective step to reduce future exacerbations?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Smoking is a significant environmental risk factor that worsens Crohn disease by increasing oxidative stress, promoting pro-inflammatory cytokine release, and disrupting mucosal immune functions. These effects lead to heightened intestinal inflammation and more frequent disease flare-ups. Patients with Crohn disease who smoke have higher relapse rates and increased complications, such as the need for immunosuppressive therapy or surgery. Smoking cessation is a modifiable risk factor that can improve disease control and reduce the severity and frequency of future exacerbations.

Key learning point: Cigarette smoking is a significant environmental risk factor for the development and exacerbation of Crohn disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic bowel resection is not recommended for preventing Crohn disease flare-ups. Surgery is reserved for complications like strictures or fistulas. The disease can recur after resection, as it involves segmental inflammation that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are effective for inducing remission in acute Crohn disease exacerbations but are not suitable for long-term maintenance due to severe adverse effects, including osteoporosis and adrenal suppression. They do not modify the underlying disease process, and their systemic toxicities outweigh the benefits for preventing future flare-ups.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing dietary fiber does not reduce Crohn disease exacerbations. High-fiber diets can worsen symptoms like pain and bloating, especially in patients with strictures. During active inflammation, low-residue diets are often recommended to minimize mechanical irritation.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with recurring episodes of abdominal pain primarily in the right lower quadrant, non-bloody diarrhea for five months, and a 4-kg weight loss. He occasionally notices blood streaks. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant and no perianal lesions (see reports).

Colonoscopy: Patchy areas of inflamed mucosa in the terminal ileum
Biopsy of the affected area: Granulomas lacking central necrosis

Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intestinal tuberculosis involves the ileocecal area and produces caseating granulomas, unlike the non-caseating granulomas found here. The patchy inflammation pattern is more indicative of Crohn disease than the uniform involvement seen in tuberculosis.

B) CORRECT:

Crohn disease commonly affects young adults and manifests with right lower quadrant pain, chronic diarrhea, and weight loss. The colonoscopy shows patchy inflamed mucosa in the terminal ileum, characteristic of skip lesions in Crohn disease. The biopsy reveals non-caseating granulomas, a hallmark of Crohn disease, indicating a cell-mediated immune response. Transmural inflammation in Crohn disease can lead to complications such as strictures and fistulas.

Key learning point: Non-caseating granulomas in the terminal ileum are characteristic of Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis presents with continuous mucosal inflammation starting in the rectum, not patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum. It lacks granulomas, unlike the non-caseating granulomas seen in this case. The presence of skip lesions and granulomas suggests Crohn disease rather than ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease affects the proximal small intestine, particularly the duodenum, with villous atrophy and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. The patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum and non-caseating granulomas are inconsistent with celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of progressively worsening abdominal pain, predominantly in the right lower quadrant, and watery diarrhea occurring up to five times daily. He has lost 5 kg over this period. During the last month, he has experienced a painful swelling near his anus that intermittently drains fluid. He is otherwise healthy. Vital signs reveal a low-grade fever (see lab results and reports).

Temperature
37.8 °C



Test
Result
Normal Values



C-reactive peptide
15 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Hemoglobin
112 g/L
130 - 170 g/L




Colonoscopy: Scattered inflammatory lesions in the terminal ileum separated by segments of normal-appearing mucosa
Biopsy: Pending result

Which finding is most characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Diffuse mucosal involvement limited to the colon
Transmural inflammatory infiltrates with noncaseating granulomas
Continuous superficial erosions restricted to the rectum and sigmoid
Subepithelial collagen band with minimal inflammatory changes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse mucosal involvement limited to the colon is typical of ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous inflammation starting from the rectum. The colonoscopy findings of scattered lesions in the terminal ileum and the presence of perianal disease suggest Crohn disease, which features discontinuous 'skip' lesions and transmural inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation, often affecting the terminal ileum with patchy 'skip' lesions. This inflammation can lead to complications such as fistulas and strictures. Histologically, noncaseating granulomas, which are aggregates of activated macrophages, are a hallmark of Crohn disease. These features align with the patient's symptoms of right lower quadrant pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and perianal disease, as well as the colonoscopy findings of scattered lesions.

Key learning point: Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural inflammation and skip lesions, most commonly affecting the ileum, and can present with symptoms such as weight loss, abdominal pain, and perianal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous superficial erosions in the rectum and sigmoid are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. The patient's colonoscopy shows scattered lesions in the terminal ileum with normal intervening mucosa, indicating a 'skip' lesion pattern typical of Crohn disease, not the continuous pattern of ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A subepithelial collagen band with minimal inflammation is indicative of collagenous colitis, which presents with chronic watery diarrhea but typically shows normal mucosa on colonoscopy. The patient's significant inflammation, anemia, and colonoscopy findings suggest a more systemic inflammatory process, consistent with Crohn disease.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of intermittent crampy abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and an unintentional weight loss of 5 kg. He reports occasional nighttime awakenings due to abdominal pain and has noticed streaks of blood mixed with his stool on a few occasions. Abdominal examination reveals mild right lower quadrant tenderness without guarding or rebound (see lab results and reports).

Heart rate
100/min



Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
115 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
28 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L




Colonoscopy: Patchy areas of inflammation with normal mucosa in between
Small bowel imaging study: Multiple strictures in the terminal ileum

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease is an immune-mediated enteropathy affecting the proximal small intestine, leading to villous atrophy and malabsorption. It does not cause the segmental, transmural inflammation or strictures seen in this patient. The elevated C-reactive protein and patchy inflammation with normal mucosa are not typical of celiac disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis typically presents with continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum and extending proximally, without skip lesions. The presence of multiple strictures in the terminal ileum and patchy inflammation on colonoscopy are inconsistent with ulcerative colitis, which is confined to the colon and does not involve the small bowel.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional disorder without identifiable inflammatory or structural abnormalities. The presence of anemia, elevated C-reactive protein, patchy inflammation, and strictures in the terminal ileum, along with nighttime symptoms and weight loss, suggest an organic pathology rather than IBS.

D) CORRECT:

Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, often involving the terminal ileum. This patient presents with symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, diarrhea, nocturnal pain, and weight loss, indicative of an inflammatory process. Laboratory findings of anemia and elevated C-reactive protein suggest systemic inflammation. Colonoscopy shows patchy inflammation with normal mucosa in between, known as skip lesions, and small bowel imaging reveals strictures in the terminal ileum. These findings are consistent with Crohn disease, which is known for its segmental involvement and potential for stricturing due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

Key learning point: Multiple strictures in the small bowel, particularly in young adults, are most commonly associated with Crohn disease, which is characterized by transmural inflammation leading to strictures and obstruction.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with three days of severe right lower quadrant pain, fever, chills, and nausea to the clinic. He has a 5-year history of Crohn disease and reports decreased adherence to his usual medications for the past month. Physical examination shows localized tenderness and guarding (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
104/min


Blood pressure
116/72 mm Hg


Temperature
39.1°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
15 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Hemoglobin
112 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
80 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



CT scan of abdomen: 8-cm rim-enhancing fluid collection in the right iliac fossa
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?

choices.text: Immediate surgical resection of the affected bowel segment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While intravenous antibiotics address systemic infection and cover potential pathogens, they are insufficient for large abscesses due to limited penetration into the encapsulated purulent material. The 8-cm rim-enhancing fluid collection requires additional intervention for effective source control.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical resection is considered in cases of diffuse peritonitis or necrotic bowel. However, the CT scan shows a contained abscess, which is better managed with percutaneous drainage and antibiotics. Surgery in Crohn disease risks postoperative complications and can compromise bowel length, leading to short bowel syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Intra-abdominal abscesses in Crohn disease often require source control, especially when large, rim-enhancing fluid collections are present. Antibiotics alone have limited efficacy due to poor penetration into the abscess cavity. Image-guided percutaneous drainage effectively decompresses the abscess and allows fluid collection for culture, facilitating targeted antimicrobial therapy. This minimally invasive approach stabilizes the patient, reduces inflammation, and avoids unnecessary surgical resection, preserving bowel integrity.

Key learning point: Intra-abdominal abscesses in Crohn disease are initially managed with percutaneous drainage, which is less invasive and effective in controlling infection.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoids are used for inflammatory flares in Crohn disease but are inappropriate for infectious complications like abscesses. The immunosuppressive effects can worsen infections by inhibiting the immune response. The presence of fever, elevated inflammatory markers, and a rim-enhancing fluid collection on CT scan indicate an abscess, not a simple inflammatory exacerbation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of loose stools containing blood, lower abdominal cramps, and a 5-kg weight loss. He has no family history of similar symptoms. Examination shows mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Colonoscopy reveals patchy mucosal ulcerations in the ileum and scattered areas of normal mucosa in between. Biopsy specimens from the affected regions demonstrate transmural inflammation with discrete noncaseating granulomas (see reports).

Colonoscopy: Patchy mucosal ulcerations in the ileum; scattered areas of normal mucosa
Biopsy: Transmural inflammation with discrete noncaseating granulomas

Which condition is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis generally affects older patients and involves mucosal and submucosal layers, not transmural inflammation. It rarely affects the ileum and does not present with noncaseating granulomas, making it unlikely in this young patient with the described findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis presents with continuous mucosal and submucosal inflammation starting in the rectum, without skip lesions. The patchy ulcerations and ileal involvement seen here are inconsistent with its typical pattern. Additionally, ulcerative colitis does not exhibit transmural inflammation or noncaseating granulomas.

C) CORRECT:

The 19-year-old man's symptoms of bloody diarrhea, weight loss, and right lower quadrant tenderness, along with colonoscopy findings of patchy ulcerations and normal mucosa, indicate skip lesions, characteristic of Crohn disease. Biopsy shows transmural inflammation and noncaseating granulomas, further supporting Crohn disease, which involves all intestinal wall layers and often affects the terminal ileum, explaining the tenderness.

Key learning point: Non-caseating granulomas on biopsy are a distinguishing feature of Crohn disease, whereas ulcerative colitis does not typically present with granulomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious colitis usually presents acutely and resolves quickly, unlike the chronic symptoms and weight loss here. It typically shows continuous mucosal involvement, not patchy ulcerations. Transmural inflammation and noncaseating granulomas are atypical for infectious colitis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-year history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. She reports a 10-kg weight loss over the past 10 months. On examination, she has a mildly distended abdomen, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the anterior aspect of both legs. There is a small draining lesion in the perianal region. Further evaluation of her gastrointestinal tract is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
