questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crypt abscesses are a typical histopathologic finding in ulcerative colitis (UC). They are also seen in patients with CD but are far more common in patients with UC. UC can manifest with erythema nodosum, severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. However, it is quite rare to see fistula formation in UC because inflammation is localized in the mucosal and submucosal layers.

B) INCORRECT:

No structural abnormalities of the gastrointestinal tract in a patient with abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea would be concerning for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Though IBS could cause some of this patient's symptoms, it is not associated with findings like erythema nodosum or fistulas. In addition, patients with IBS generally appear healthy and do not typically manifest with weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Neuroendocrine tumor cells are found in carcinoid tumors. Diarrhea and abdominal cramps may occur as part of carcinoid syndrome, but they are usually accompanied by other findings such as cutaneous flushing and bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea). Moreover, carcinoid tumors are not associated with erythema nodosum or fistulas.

D) INCORRECT:

Villous atrophy is a typical histopathologic finding in celiac disease. This condition can manifest with abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, extraintestinal symptoms are more common (e.g., vitamin deficiencies, dermatitis herpetiformis, depression, osteoporosis). This patient's erythema nodosum and fistulas are not associated with celiac disease.

E) CORRECT:

Transmural intestinal inflammation is a characteristic finding of CD. It commonly results in abscess and fistula formation. Endoscopy confirms the diagnosis, showing a discontinuous pattern of involvement with linear ulcers (“snail trails”) and a cobblestone appearance of the affected GI areas (typically terminal ileum and colon). Biopsy reveals inflammation of all intestinal layers and noncaseating granulomas.

Key learning point: Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, often leading to fistulas, abscesses, and discontinuous lesions with a cobblestone appearance.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a colon biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Infiltrating neutrophils (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the crypts in the upper part of the image. A noncaseating granuloma (green overlay) is visible in the lower part of the image.

These features indicate transmural inflammation, which is a characteristic finding of Crohn disease.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a perianal fistula with drainage in combination with erythema nodosum (multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the legs) are suggestive of a diagnosis of Crohn disease (CD).

questions.text: You are seeing a 62-year-old man in the emergency department with right-sided back pain, nausea, and dark urine. He describes alternating episodes of decreased and increased urine output over the past 2 days. Over the past year, he has had two urinary tract infections. His medical history includes Crohn disease and a small bowel resection 5 years ago. His current medications are mesalamine and a multivitamin. On examination, he has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. Which one of the following factors has most likely contributed most to his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective tubular amino acid reabsorption is the underlying cause of cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder that increases the risk of cystine stones. However, in cystinuria, stone formation would typically manifest in childhood and hexagon-shaped crystals would be seen on urinalysis, rather than the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, a positive sodium nitroprusside test would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

High urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, which appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. An alkaline environment increases the concentration of dibasic phosphate (HPO42-) in the urine, which is prone to bind to dicationic calcium (Ca2+) to form calcium phosphate stones. A high urine pH is also a risk factor for the formation of struvite stones, which appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lids) on urinalysis. In contrast, a low urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of oxalate stones.

C) INCORRECT:

A parathyroid gland adenoma could cause pathologically increased secretion of parathyroid hormone and lead to clinical hyperparathyroidism. This often results in hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, which contribute to calcium stone formation. These stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate stones, but the risk of calcium phosphate stones is also increased. This patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., weakness, constipation, irritability), making hyperparathyroidism less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) increase the risk of struvite stones. This patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections; however, they are unlikely to be the cause of his stones. Struvite stones would appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid appearance) on urinalysis, not the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Struvite stones are often quite large and fill the entire renal pelvis and calyces on imaging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Malabsorption of fatty acids due to deficiency in bile acids is common in patients with Crohn disease (and/or short bowel syndrome) and likely explains this patient's nephrolithiasis. In the intestinal lumen, undigested fatty acids chelate calcium, which would normally bind oxalate and lead to its excretion in the feces. Patients with Crohn disease often have pathologically increased luminal oxalate and increased oxalate absorption. After entering the serum, oxalate is excreted in the urine (hyperoxaluria), where it binds calcium and forms calcium oxalate stones.

Episodes of increased urination followed by oliguria are caused by temporary ureteral obstruction by stones. If a ureter is blocked, urine cannot pass through. When the obstruction is relieved, copious urine flows into the bladder.

Key learning point: Crohn disease and small bowel resection can cause fat malabsorption, leading to increased intestinal oxalate absorption and a higher risk of calcium oxalate kidney stones.
questions.hint: Envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis indicate calcium oxalate crystals.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-week history of loose, nonbloody stools, abdominal pain, intermittent nausea, and fever. On abdominal examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. CT scan of the abdomen reveals transmural thickening and fat stranding in discrete regions of the terminal ileum and transverse colon. Colonoscopy with biopsy of the affected areas is performed. Which one of the following findings is most specific for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa.
Poorly differentiated gland-forming cells with desmoplasia.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa is a histopathologic finding of ulcerative colitis (UC), which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fever. However, stool in UC is typically grossly bloody and contains mucus. Additionally, a CT scan of the abdomen would most likely show continuous inflammation starting in the rectum, in contrast to the discrete regions of inflammation in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Poorly differentiated gland-forming cells with desmoplasia of the surrounding connective tissue is a histopathologic finding of colon cancer, which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, and nausea. However, colon cancer would be unlikely in a 24-year-old patient without a significant family history. Moreover, it would have likely appeared as a soft tissue density narrowing the bowel lumen on abdominal CT scan.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudopolyps can be found in Crohn disease (CD), but they are not specific to the condition. In fact, they are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis (UC). UC may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fever. However, stool in UC is typically grossly bloody and contains mucus. A CT scan of the abdomen would most likely show continuous inflammation starting in the rectum, in contrast to the discrete regions of inflammation in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Formation of noncaseating granulomas is a histopathological finding in ∼ 30% of patients with CD. While the absence of granulomas does not rule out CD, their presence helps to distinguish CD from ulcerative colitis. This distinction can be challenging, especially in CD involving the colon. Distinguishing between the two conditions is crucial, however, as their management differs significantly. On biopsy, the presence of granulomatous inflammation, transmural inflammation, fissures, and aphthous ulcers would strongly suggest CD.

See “Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis” table.

Key learning point: Noncaseating granulomas on biopsy are the most specific histopathological finding for Crohn disease, helping to distinguish it from ulcerative colitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the cecum (H&E stain; low magnification)

Large numbers of lymphocytes, giant cells, and epithelioid cells are seen clustered around a large granuloma.

This is a typical histological finding in Crohn disease.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil-rich pseudomembranes are a histopathologic finding of clostridium enterocolitis, which may also present with abdominal pain, loose stools, nausea, and fevers. However, clostridium enterocolitis typically presents following antibiotic treatment, which facilitates overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile in the intestinal tract. Unlike in this patient, the loose stools are usually watery and characteristically foul-smelling. Inflammation of the colonic mucosa causes fibrinous exudate, which manifests as pseudomembranes.
questions.hint: This young man has abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, laboratory evidence of inflammation, and a CT scan of the abdomen showing skip lesions in the colon with transmural inflammation and sparing of the rectum. Given that the infectious workup was negative, autoimmune enteritis is high on the differential. Crohn disease (CD) is more likely than ulcerative colitis based on the CT scan and the absence of tenesmus, gross bleeding, and rectal pain.

questions.text: A 28-year-woman with known Crohn disease presents with 4 days of crampy right lower quadrant pain, bloody diarrhea, and fever. Vital signs are BP, 100/70; P, 100; T, 40.1°C (104.2°F). Physical examination shows pain to palpation in the lower right quadrant without guarding or rebound. CT shows terminal ileal wall thickening and adjacent fluid collection measuring 3.5 cm. Laboratory studies show WBC 14,500/mm3 and elevated CRP. In addition to fluid resuscitation, what is the most appropriate nest step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is an immunomodulator primarily used for maintenance therapy in Crohn disease (CD). It can also be used in induction regimens for moderate to severe CD, but this patient has severe to fulminant CD based on high fever and abscess formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Controlled ileal release budesonide is appropriate for mild to moderate Crohn disease limited to the ileum and right colon. This patient has severe to fulminant disease based on high fever and abscess formation and requires more intensive therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine is primarily used in ulcerative colitis. It can be considered in mild to moderate Crohn disease (CD), but this patient has severe to fulminant CD.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is used for induction therapy in mild to moderate Crohn disease (CD). This patient's presentation with high fever and abscess formation indicates severe to fulminant disease requiring more aggressive therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has severe to fulminant Crohn disease based on high fever and abscess formation. IV methylprednisolone combined with infliximab is used in induction therapy for severe to fulminant disease. This patient will also require gastroenterology consultation and broad-spectrum antibiotics and early surgical consultation due to abscess formation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of Crohn disease presents to the emergency department with 2 days of crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has had minimal stool output over the past 24 hours and has vomited five times over the past hour. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 105; R, 22; T, 37.9°C (100.2°F). On examination, his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show potassium 3.1 mEq/L. Abdominal radiograph shows multiple dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Insert a nasogastric tube and initiate IV fluids
Administer IV corticosteroids and establish NPO status
Obtain CT abdomen with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has small bowel obstruction and has significant abdominal distention and vomiting, which are specific indications for nasogastric decompression. IV fluids are needed to address the hypokalemia. These are immediate stabilization measures before further evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has severe to fulminant Crohn disease with bowel obstruction. While IV corticosteroids are used in the treatment of severe to fulminant Crohn disease, another step in management is needed first.

C) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not routinely indicated for simple bowel obstruction. Another step in management is needed urgently.

D) INCORRECT:

Although CT imaging is the gold standard for bowel obstruction diagnosis, obtaining imaging should not delay emergency stabilization.

E) INCORRECT:

While prokinetics can be used in the treatment of paralytic ileus, this patient with a history of Crohn disease more likely has mechanical bowel obstruction. Another step in management is needed urgently.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and poor weight gain. The abdominal pain is crampy, often occurs after meals, and is partially relieved by defecation. He has had 3 to 4 bowel movements per day, sometimes with streaks of blood. His parents report that he has become increasingly fatigued and has fallen behind his peers in growth. His past medical history is notable for recurrent aphthous ulcers in his mouth. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. The patient appears thin and pale. Abdominal examination reveals mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Perianal examination shows a skin tag and a small fistula. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 45 mm/h, and C-reactive protein level is 15 mg/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) often manifests with intermittent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits, but it does not cause bloody diarrhea, weight loss, growth failure, anemia, or elevated inflammatory markers. Additionally, IBS is not associated with extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., oral ulcers).

B) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) commonly manifests with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and anemia. However, UC is limited to the colon and therefore does not manifest with aphthous ulcers or perianal fistulas. Additionally, diarrhea in UC is most often bloody with mucus rather than watery.

C) INCORRECT:

Giardiasis can manifest with chronic diarrhea and abdominal discomfort in children. However, giardiasis does not manifest with growth failure, perianal disease, extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., aphthous ulcers), or the laboratory findings (anemia, elevated inflammatory markers) seen in this patient. In addition, giardiasis is typically more acute in onset and causes greasy, foul-smelling stools.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease in children commonly manifests with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and growth failure. However, this patient presents with perianal features (e.g., skin tags, fistulas) that do not manifest in celiac disease. Additionally, dermatitis herpetiformis rather than aphthous ulcer is an extraintestinal manifestation of this condition.

E) CORRECT:

Crohn disease in children typically manifests with chronic, crampy abdominal pain, watery diarrhea with occasional blood, weight loss, and growth failure. This condition also often manifests with extraintestinal features, such as oral ulcers. Common laboratory findings include microcytic anemia and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR, CRP). Crohn disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, often with segmental transmural inflammation leading to complications such as fistulas and strictures. Children are especially prone to growth failure due to malabsorption and chronic inflammation.
questions.hint: Colonoscopy findings in patients with this condition include ulcerations, strictures, fistulas, and skip lesions.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of intermittent, crampy right lower quadrant abdominal pain and non-bloody diarrhea. He reports an unintentional 15-lb weight loss and fatigue. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, he is afebrile with a heart rate of 95/min. There is tenderness to deep palpation in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 11.8 g/dL and an elevated C-reactive protein. A colonoscopy with biopsies is performed. Which of the following findings is most specific for the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Crypt abscesses with preserved goblet cells
Continuous inflammation limited to the mucosal layer
Pseudomembranes composed of fibrin and inflammatory cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crypt abscesses, which are collections of neutrophils within the crypts of Lieberkühn, can be seen in both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Therefore, this finding is not specific for the suspected diagnosis. In fact, crypt abscesses are often more numerous and prominent in ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

This histologic pattern describes ulcerative colitis, not Crohn disease. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that begins in the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous fashion, and the inflammation is typically confined to the mucosal and submucosal layers. This patient's non-bloody diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain make ulcerative colitis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

This finding is pathognomonic for pseudomembranous colitis, an infection caused by Clostridioides difficile. While it causes diarrhea, it typically presents as an acute illness often following antibiotic use, not as a chronic, 6-month history of intermittent symptoms as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

While not present in all cases, the finding of noncaseating granulomas on biopsy is the most specific histological feature distinguishing Crohn disease from other inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis. These are organized collections of macrophages. Other characteristic findings of Crohn disease include transmural inflammation (involving all layers of the bowel wall), which can lead to complications like fistulas and strictures, and skip lesions, where inflamed segments of bowel are separated by areas of normal mucosa. The patient's right lower quadrant pain suggests involvement of the terminal ileum, the most common site for Crohn disease.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the classic histological finding for celiac disease. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten that causes malabsorption, which could explain the weight loss and diarrhea. However, the prominent right lower quadrant pain and elevated inflammatory markers are more characteristic of inflammatory bowel disease than uncomplicated celiac disease.
questions.hint: This young patient's presentation of chronic right lower quadrant pain, weight loss, and non-bloody diarrhea, along with an elevated C-reactive protein, are suggestive of Crohn disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of intermittent, crampy right lower quadrant abdominal pain and non-bloody diarrhea. She reports having 4-5 loose stools daily, fatigue, and an unintentional 12-pound weight loss. She also notes painful sores in her mouth that come and go. Her vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals a thin-appearing female with several oral aphthous ulcers. Her abdomen is soft with moderate tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant, without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dL, a low mean corpuscular volume, and an elevated C-reactive protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for Crohn disease. Key features include the insidious onset in a young adult, crampy right lower quadrant pain (suggesting terminal ileum involvement), non-bloody diarrhea, and significant weight loss (indicating malabsorption). The presence of extraintestinal manifestations like oral aphthous ulcers supports the diagnosis, as Crohn disease can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus. Laboratory findings of microcytic anemia and elevated C-reactive protein point to a chronic inflammatory process with malabsorption or blood loss. Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation which can lead to complications like strictures, fistulas, and abscesses.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can manifest with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and microcytic anemia due to malabsorption. However, prominent, localized right lower quadrant pain and a significantly elevated C-reactive protein are not typical features. While aphthous ulcers can occur, the constellation of symptoms is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome can cause chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, it is a functional disorder and does not cause objective signs of inflammation or pathology. The presence of weight loss, oral ulcers, microcytic anemia, and an elevated C-reactive protein indicates an organic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Yersinia enterocolitica can cause fever, diarrhea, and right lower quadrant pain by causing terminal ileitis, mimicking appendicitis or a Crohn flare. However, this is an acute infectious process. This patient's symptoms have been present for six months, which is inconsistent with an acute bacterial infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that typically manifests with bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and lower abdominal pain, often in the left lower quadrant. The inflammation is limited to the mucosal layer of the colon. This patient's non-bloody diarrhea, prominent right lower quadrant pain, significant weight loss, and oral ulcers make this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a 5-year history of ileocolonic Crohn disease presents with three weeks of worsening perianal pain and purulent drainage. He was previously maintained on mesalamine but recently required a course of oral prednisone with only partial improvement. On examination, there is an external opening with purulent drainage at the 5 o'clock perianal position. An MRI confirms a simple transsphincteric fistula without an associated abscess. His C-reactive protein is elevated at 35 mg/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to initiate for long-term management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ustekinumab, an inhibitor of interleukins 12 and 23, is an effective therapy for moderate-to-severe Crohn disease. However, the evidence supporting its efficacy for fistula healing is less robust than that for anti-TNF agents like infliximab. It is generally considered a second-line biologic option, often used in patients who have failed or are intolerant to anti-TNF therapy, rather than the initial choice for active fistulizing disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics like metronidazole are frequently used as adjunctive therapy in perianal Crohn disease to reduce bacterial load and manage symptoms of purulent drainage. However, antibiotics do not address the underlying inflammatory process that causes the fistula. They are not effective for long-term fistula healing or for controlling the overall disease activity and therefore are not appropriate as the primary long-term management.

C) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is an immunomodulator used for maintenance of remission in Crohn disease and as a steroid-sparing agent. While it is often used in combination with biologics to enhance their effect, it is not effective as a monotherapy for inducing closure of an active fistula. Its onset of action is very slow, typically taking three to six months to become fully effective, making it inappropriate for this patient's acute symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Vedolizumab is a gut-selective anti-integrin biologic approved for moderate-to-severe Crohn disease. While it is effective for achieving remission in luminal disease, clinical trial data shows it is significantly less effective and has a slower onset of action for closing perianal fistulas compared to anti-TNF agents. Therefore, it is not the preferred first-line biologic for this patient's specific presentation of fistulizing Crohn disease.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has moderate-to-severe Crohn disease with an active perianal fistula, which is a clear indication for initiating biologic therapy. Infliximab, a monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), is the most well-studied and effective agent for inducing and maintaining fistula closure in Crohn disease. Anti-TNF agents are considered first-line biologic therapy for fistulizing disease due to their ability to rapidly reduce the transmural inflammation that drives fistula formation. The presence of an elevated C-reactive protein and a partial response to steroids further supports the need for a more potent, long-term therapy to control the underlying disease activity and heal the fistula. Combination therapy with an immunomodulator like azathioprine is often used to increase efficacy and reduce antibody formation to infliximab.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a moderate-to-severe Crohn disease with an active perianal fistula.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of intermittent, crampy lower abdominal pain and non-bloody diarrhea. She reports associated fatigue and an unintentional 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. She also reports recurrent, painful sores in her mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies show a normocytic anemia and an elevated C-reactive protein. A colonoscopy shows patchy areas of inflammation with deep, linear ulcers in the terminal ileum and ascending colon, separated by segments of normal-appearing mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can manifest with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and anemia due to malabsorption. However, it is an autoimmune disorder affecting the small intestine, primarily the duodenum and jejunum, in response to gluten. It does not cause the deep, patchy ulcerations in the colon and terminal ileum seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis is a major differential diagnosis for inflammatory bowel disease. However, it typically manifests with bloody diarrhea, as the inflammation is continuous and confined to the colonic mucosa, starting in the rectum. The findings of skip lesions and terminal ileum involvement are inconsistent with ulcerative colitis.

C) CORRECT:

Crohn disease is an inflammatory bowel disease characterized by transmural inflammation that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus. Typical features of Crohn disease include non-bloody diarrhea, right lower quadrant pain (reflecting ileitis), weight loss, and extraintestinal manifestations such as aphthous ulcers. The colonoscopy findings are pathognomonic: involvement of the terminal ileum, patchy inflammation with intervening normal mucosa (skip lesions), and deep, linear ulcers that can create a cobblestone appearance. The elevated inflammatory markers and anemia of chronic disease further support this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

While an infection can cause diarrhea and abdominal pain, the 4-month duration makes an acute infectious cause unlikely. Chronic infections such as intestinal tuberculosis can mimic this presentation, but the combination of oral ulcers, non-bloody diarrhea, and classic endoscopic findings of skip lesions strongly suggests another condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome can cause chronic crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, it is a functional disorder and would not be associated with objective signs of inflammation such as weight loss, anemia, elevated C-reactive protein, or the presence of ulcers on colonoscopy.
questions.hint: The pattern of inflammation, specifically the presence of skip lesions and involvement of the terminal ileum, is highly suggestive of this condition.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with a two-month history of intermittent abdominal cramps and non-bloody diarrhea to the clinic. She reports fatigue, an 8-lb weight loss, and painful red bumps on her shins that appeared two weeks ago. She has no rectal bleeding or recent antibiotic use. Physical examination reveals warm, tender nodules on both lower legs. Stool studies are negative for infections.
Laboratory results show mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers. Which underlying condition is most closely associated with these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can present with diarrhea, weight loss, and anemia, but its skin manifestation is dermatitis herpetiformis, characterized by pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces. The patient's tender nodules on the shins are consistent with erythema nodosum, not dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Diverticular disease, including diverticulitis, typically occurs in older patients and presents with acute localized abdominal pain, not a prolonged history of intermittent symptoms. It is not associated with systemic features or cutaneous findings like erythema nodosum.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms of abdominal cramps, non-bloody diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and elevated inflammatory markers suggest Crohn disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. The tender, warm nodules on her shins are consistent with erythema nodosum, an extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn disease. This condition involves transmural inflammation and can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to systemic symptoms and cutaneous manifestations. The interplay between gastrointestinal inflammation and immune responses in Crohn disease explains the presence of erythema nodosum.

Key learning point: Erythema nodosum, presenting as tender red nodules on the shins, is associated with inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn disease, and not typically with conditions like IBS or diverticular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is characterized by chronic abdominal pain and altered bowel habits without objective inflammatory markers, weight loss, or systemic manifestations. IBS does not cause extraintestinal findings like erythema nodosum, which is seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during this time. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen, hyperactive bowel sounds, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. A biopsy specimen of the colonic mucosa shows scattered areas of inflammation with fibrosis and noncaseating granulomas. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased secretion of IL-4 and IL-13
Increased activity of type 1 T helper cells
Accumulation of intracellular bacteria in macrophages

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased secretion of IL-4 and IL-13 is the main underlying mechanism of ulcerative colitis (UC), which is primarily mediated by Th2 cells. Patients with UC also have abdominal pain, bloating, and bloody diarrhea. However, biopsies would reveal inflammation restricted to the mucosa and submucosa, crypt abscesses, and an absence of granulomas.

B) CORRECT:

Type 1 T helper cell (Th1 cell) activity mediates the inflammatory processes involved in Crohn disease (CD). The release of proinflammatory cytokines by Th1 cells (e.g., IFN-γ), activates macrophages, which then cause local tissue damage, fibrotic scarring, and the formation of characteristic skip lesions throughout most of the gastrointestinal tract (sparing the rectum). Macrophage activation also leads to the formation of noncaseating granulomas in inflammatory tissue, another distinctive sign of CD.

See “Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Ectopic secretion of serotonin is caused by carcinoid tumors. When such tumors grow downstream of the liver (bypassing first-pass metabolism) or overwhelm the portal circulation, excess serotonin results in carcinoid syndrome. Although this patient has abdominal pain and diarrhea, he does not have other symptoms of carcinoid syndrome (i.e., wheezing, dyspnea, flushing). Moreover, a biopsy would not show scattered areas of inflammation with fibrosis and noncaseating granulomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic intestinal overgrowth of toxigenic bacteria (e.g., E. coli and Enterobacter) manifests with severe gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea) and weight loss (malnutrition). However, biopsy would reveal shortened, blunted villi and elongated crypts, with WBCs infiltrating the lamina propria, not a scattered pattern of inflammation and scarring.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of antibodies against antitissue transglutaminase is a specific indicator of celiac disease. These antibodies target gluten molecules attached to transglutaminase, resulting in a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction within the intestinal mucosa. Patients with celiac disease experience abdominal pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. However, a biopsy would show flat mucosa with loss of villi and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, not the scattered pattern of inflammation and scarring found in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

An accumulation of intracellular bacteria in intestinal macrophages would cause signs of gastrointestinal distress (e.g., abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea). Examples of such bacteria include Tropheryma whipplei (which causes Whipple disease) and Mycobacterium avium intracellulare. However, because this patient's biopsy showed no signs of intracellular bacteria within macrophages, but instead a scattered pattern of inflammation and scarring, Crohn disease is much more likely in this case.
questions.hint: In combination with gastrointestinal distress (abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea), a biopsy specimen of colonic mucosa showing scattered areas of inflammation with fibrosis and noncaseating granulomas indicates Crohn disease.
